title: Protocol to Design, Clone, and Validate sgRNAs for In Vivo Reverse Genetic Studies

Step-By-Step Method Details
Insertion of sgRNAs into Vector
Timing: 5 days
Day 1. Vector Digestion using BsaI
Set up the following reaction using vector of choice (Figures 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]D and 1E):
table:files/protocols_protocol_112_4.csv
Digest 16 h (overnight) at 37°C.
Day 2. Part One – Purification of cut vector
Add 2 μL of Quick CIP and allow reaction to go for 30 min at 37°C.
Run the cut vector on a 1% agarose gel and perform a gel extraction using the Qiagen gel extraction kit following manufacturer instructions.
Note: The linear vector should run at ∼7.8 kb.
Day 2. Part Two – Anneal and phosphorylate each pair of oligos
Note: Part Two can be completed simultaneously with Part One.
Combine the following reagents:
table:files/protocols_protocol_112_5.csv
Incubate for 30 min at 37°C.
Boil the reaction at 100°C for 5 min.
Turn off the heat and allow the reaction to slowly reach 20°C–22°C (room temperature).
Alternatives: This can also be completed using a ramp down protocol in a thermocycler.
Day 2. Part Three – Ligate the phosphorylated and annealed oligos into the cut vector
Add 1 μL T4 ligase and ∼50 ng of cut vector directly to the reaction from Part Two.
Allow the ligation to sit at 20°C–22°C (room temperature) for 3 h.
Remove excess salts via dialysis.
Transform 1.5 μL of the ligation using 25 μL DH10B electrocompetent E. coli cells.
After transformation, quickly resuspend in 500 μL LB.
Allow 1-h recovery in 37°C with shaking and then plate 100 μL on LB + 100 μg/mL AMP antibiotic plates.
Allow the colonies to grow 12–16 h at 37°C.
Pause Point: Plate may be stored at 4°C for multiple days.
Day 3. Colony selection and miniprep setup

Set up eight minipreps using 3 mL LB + 100 μg/mL AMP in 14 mL tubes that allow aeration.
Place in 37°C with 250 rpm shaking for 12–16 h.
Day 4. DNA purification and validation of sgRNA insertion
Perform a miniprep of each of the colonies using the Qiagen miniprep kit to extract the plasmid DNA according to manufacturer instructions.
Prepare the following reaction for each purified colony DNA:
table:files/protocols_protocol_112_6.csv
Let each reaction go 3–4 h at 37°C.
Run a 1% gel to determine if the oligos inserted.
Note: Insertion of the sgRNA into the vector will produce a single band at 7.8 kb. Failure to insert the sgRNA will result in two bands (2.5 kb and 5.3 kb).
Select a colony and add 200 μL from miniprep culture in 200 mL LB + 100 μg/mL AMP in a 1L Erlenmeyer flask. Incubate 16 h (overnight) at 37°C with 250 rpm.
Day 5. Purification of plasmid DNA
Perform a maxiprep using the Invitrogen maxiprep kit.
Send the DNA to Genewiz for sequencing using the U6 Genewiz Universal primer (sequence: GACTATCATATGCTTACCGT).
Pause Point: The product can be stored at −20°C for years.
Viral Package, Injection, and Expression
Timing: >7 weeks
Package plasmids into AAVs.
Note: For packaging DNA into AAVs, please refer to (Gore et al., 2013[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]) for step by step instructions or use a commercial AAV packaging facility.
Critical: AAV serotypes and titer for AAV-FLEX-SaCas9-sgRNA and AAV-FLEX-EGFP-KASH or AAV-FLEXfrt-SaCas9-sgRNA and AAV-FLEXfrt-EGFP-KASH must be the same to maximize co-transduction efficiencies.
Co-inject Cre- or Flp-expressing animals with newly synthesized AAV-FLEX-SaCas9-sgRNA or AAV-FLEXfrt-SaCas9-sgRNA (targeting your gene of choice) and AAV-FLEX-EGFP-KASH or AAV-FLEXfrt-EGFP-KASH, respectively (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A).

Figure 2. Process for the Validation of sgRNAs In Vivo
(A) Schematic of AAV co-injections into the mouse brain.

(B) Schematic of workflow necessary to prepare nuclei for FACS.
(C) Left: Schematic of proper gating to isolate GFP-negative and GFP-positive nuclei. Right: Example FACS with GFP-negative and GFP-positive gates labeled.
(D) Schematic of workflow for the generation and sequencing of amplicons following FACS. Red arrow: SaCas9 cleavage site.
Note: KASH is a protein domain that is inserted into the nuclear envelope. EGFP-KASH integrates EGFP into the nuclear envelope to appropriately identify virally transduced nuclei by EGFP fluorescence (Swiech et al., 2015[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9]).
Critical: Viral concentrations should be between 1 and 3 × 1012 particles per mL and injected at a volume of 0.5 mL and rate of 0.25 mL/min. AAV-FLEX-SaCas9-sgRNA and AAV-FLEX-EGFP-KASH should be mixed at equal ratios. Optimal injection volumes, ratios, and viral titers should be tested to ensure optimal expression for each targeted cell type and brain region.
Critical: Allow 4 weeks minimum post-surgery for viral expression, and SaCas9 targeting and genomic DNA cleavage before beginning the next section.
Validation of sgRNA
Timing: 2 days
Day 1. Part One – Homogenize tissue and isolate nuclei
Timing: 1–1.5 h
At 4 weeks (or longer) following viral injection, harvest tissues from the injected animals. If harvesting from a localized brain region, slice brain into relatively thin (approx. 500 μm) coronal slices using a precision mouse brain slicer and biopsy punch. 3–6 tissue punches weighing <2 mg each can be combined into a single reaction.
Place 2 mL of cold homogenization buffer in a 2 mL Dounce homogenizer. Keep everything on ice.
Extract the tissue containing the virus injection using a small Biopsy punch.
Note: If there is a large amount of tissue, simply divide the tissue into multiple reactions. Too much tissue inhibits efficient homogenization.

Note: Tissue from the same region with no viral manipulations is a good negative control for setting gates for FACS. See step 11c for additional instruction.
Pause Point: Tissue may be flash frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at −80°C.
Place the tissue directly into 2 mL of homogenization buffer (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B).
Homogenize the brain slices first by using Dounce A 25x. Then switch to Dounce B 25x.
Pipette this into a 15 mL conical tube on ice.
Add 3 mL of homogenization buffer to bring the volume to 5 mL. Keep on ice for 5 min.
Add 5 mL of Upper gradient centrifugation buffer and mix by inversion.
Gently load on top of 10 mL of the lower gradient centrifugation buffer into 1 × 3½ Beckman tubes.
Centrifuge at 7,150 × g for 30 min at 4°C.
Remove the suspended debris using a KimWipe and then gently decant the supernatant.
Resuspend in 500–1,000 μL sterile 1× PBS.
Day 1. Part Two – FACS using a BD AriaFACS III
Timing: 1 h
Place 3 μL of REPLI-g Advanced Single Cell Storage buffer (Qiagen) into each well of an 8-well PCR strip. Keep everything on ice.
Sort using the 70 μm nozzle in single cell mode on a BD AriaFACS III. Sort 500 nuclei per well, which results in 1 μL of sorted cell suspension per well.
Design gates by comparing the negative control (no viral manipulations) to the experimental group. The GFP-positive gate should contain no GFP-negative nuclei as determined by the negative control (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C). Load the negative control and position the GFP-positive gate such that it contains zero GFP-negative nuclei.
Sort both GFP-positive and GFP-negative nuclei.
After the sort, keep the samples on ice.

Pause Point: Samples may be frozen at −80°C or used directly for whole genome amplification (WGA).
Day 1. Part Three – Whole genome amplification
Timing: 2.5 h
Perform whole genome amplification (WGA) using the REPLI-g Advanced Single Cell kit (Qiagen) according to manufacturer’s instructions (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]D).
Note: WGA is used to limit bias during PCR amplification.
Dilute 2 μL of WGA FACS DNA into 100 μL of H2O (1:50) and store at 4°C.
Pause Point: 1:50 WGA FACS DNA can be stored at 4°C, and the remaining WGA FACS DNA at −20°C for long-term storage.

Amplicon-EZ submission
Please refer to Genewiz: Amplicon-EZ service for exact submission guidelines.
Necessary items:
Reference sequence of amplicon
PCR 2 forward and reverse primers sequence
500 ng (20 ng/μL) of amplicons
